reviewText: "Fracture" trods upon very familiar ground for mystery lovers; a genius (Anthony Hopkins) plans and executes the 'Perfect Crime', and it's up to a young 'blue collar but upwardly mobile' D.A. reviewText: I love watching two people engaged in a mind game, with their subtle attempts at one-upping each other through carefully choreographed manipulation. The chemistry between Anthony Hopkins and Ryan Gosling in "Fracture" is tense, practically thick enough to cut with a knife; their characters play off of each other so well, both with personalities that are intense and restrained at the same time. How appropriate for a film about committing the perfect crime and trying like mad to catch the criminal. What makes this case especially interesting is that the criminal is, physically speaking, within reach. Legally speaking, well, that's another story; the crime was planned and executed with extreme precision, leaving virtually nothing for the legal system to work with.This emphasis on craftiness and personal style made for quite an engrossing experience, made even better by a solid plot and decent performances. Hopkins plays engineer Ted Crawford, a man of considerable control with an eye for exactness (to understand what I mean, watch the scenes featuring his homemade marble contraption). Through discreet observation, he learns that his wife, Jennifer (Embeth Davidtz), has been having an affair with Officer Rob Nunally (Billy Burke). As one might expect, this is far from acceptable in Crawford's eyes; what's not so expected is how far he'll go in expressing his anger. To show her who's actually in control, he meets her at home and shoots her in the head.Thus begins a seemingly never-ending Cat and Mouse game. Unaware that the crime scene is his lover's home, Nunally arrives to negotiate with Crawford. To everyone's surprise, Crawford confesses, despite the fact that the spent shell casings were wiped clean and that he had already burned his clothing. After being arrested (and physically assaulted by Nunally), it's one legal snag after another: forensic testing concluded that Crawford's gun had never been fired; there were no fingerprints anywhere; Nunally's testimony is useless when his infidelity is made public; Crawford's confession is inadmissible because he was supposedly provoked into giving one. All the cards seem to be stacked in Crawford's favor, and because of that, he decides to represent himself during trial.Here enters Willy Beachum (Gosling), a young Assistant DA assigned as the Prosecution Attorney. There's a quiet desperation about this character; he ambitiously aims for the private sector, which makes the pressure to succeed even greater. One gets the sense that his continuous facial ticks and hand movements are the direct result of his overachievement. He's more flawed than one might be led to believe, especially in his determination to win every case (having a ninety-seven percent success rate sure looks good on a resume). Crawford, being the sly devil he is, picks up on Beachum's personality quirks immediately. This paves the way for a series of conversations that are nothing more than puppetry; Crawford has complete control of both his situation and Beachum. This character is arrogant at a level that's both fascinating and deplorable; continuously being called "Old Sport" is enough to drive anyone over the edge.As the film progresses, a series of legal technicalities bring Crawford closer to acquittal. How disappointing for Beachum, who knows--but cannot prove--that Crawford is as guilty as sin. Of course, Crawford knows that Beachum knows, which is why he takes so much pleasure in watching the young attorney fail. If Beachum hopes to get anywhere with the case, he has to produce some evidence, namely the gun that Crawford actually used. But every time the crime scene is searched, nothing is found. Desperate to see his lover's husband get convicted, Nunally tries to convince Beachum to enter false evidence. I won't say whether or not Beachum cracks (pardon the pun); I will say that the odds against him are staggeringly high, meaning he has next to no options left.What I enjoyed most about this film was it's careful attention to character. No one was flat or underdeveloped; just enough is given for the audience to feel emotionally invested. This is especially important for a subplot involving Beachum's relationship with his new boss, Nikki Gardner (Rosamund Pike). They initially walk on eggshells around each other, the sexual tension overwhelming. When they finally sleep together, I never got the sense that it was an inappropriate inter-office fling. It felt more like a cry for release, each consumed by worlds that are crashing down around them. It's an effective counterpoint to Crawford's manipulative streak; it affects Beachum so strongly, and it seems that there's nothing that can be done.Just as strong is the tightly wound nature of the film. "Fracture" is an above average thriller, toying with the audience with a maddening sense uncertainty. Is there a way for Crawford to be caught? Has he, in fact, committed the perfect crime? I leave it to you to find out.

reviewText: With legitimate time wasting movies like "Perfect Stranger" out there I feel almost bad about picking on this one, one that I actually liked. But I liked it despite the all too familiar taste on my tongue. Willy (Ryan Gosling) is ready to move on to fame and fortune and Lakers tickets, but first he needs to close just one more case. To make the situation even better for him the case is open and shut; murder weapon, signed confession, so on and so forth. And from there things go predictably downhill. The weapon is no good, the confession is no good, the arresting officer was fornicating with the victim, so on and so forth. The script works the same way a magic trick does where we the audience spend the first half of the film watching it write itself into an airtight box and sink itself to the bottom of the ocean just so that the second half can be spent watching it escape. It is all very tired, of course the writer is smarter than the characters, but there are bits of joy to be taken from this type of story. Really it is just a high gloss version of the slop James Patterson pumps out three times a year. And no I didn't believe any of it for a second, it is pure courtroom fantasy. But I did enjoy the dark sense of humor, its half attempt at an anti-careerist message, and obviously Ryan Gosling. There is nothing here to make you rush out and see it in theaters, and its forthcoming mediocre box office receipts will prove it, but a year from now when it shows up on HBO I say give it a chance.In the opening scene director Gregory Hoblit makes an interesting decision as he goes for a good vs. bad conflict as opposed to a did he vs. didn't he one. There is no doubt in anybody's mind whether or not Ted (Anthony Hopkins) did it because we watch as he shoots her right in the face. So from then on Hoblit is stuck painting Gosling (young) as the hero and Hopkins (Not young) as the murderous husband. That means that even though Ted is the better, more likeable character we have to spend the movie pretending to root for Willy. To make this happen the writers stack the deck in his favor, he won't cheat to win the case, he turns to a selfless public servant for help and he has some sexual tension going on with a decent looking blond. Never mind that the real Willy would never do any of these things. As far as his romantic interest goes it is interesting that it isn't developed further, just kind of hinted at and then abandoned. Because if "300" has taught us anything it is that girls will accompany their boyfriends to any movie, no matter how stupid, so long as the producers throw in a half-baked love story to pacify them. For a while it looked as though the film was going to have to choose between the morality of bringing down the wife's shooter and this "don't go corporate" message that they seemed to want to spread. Of course if you have ever seen a Hollywood movie I am giving nothing away by saying that have and eat their cake. Which is fine, I forgive them. I also forgive them for this weak third act that is dragged out to provide the cliffhangers and easy resolutions that keep the masses coming back for more. I forgive mainly because Gosling is so good here. A pay check movie this is indeed, but he has charisma to spare and isn't afraid to share it. If it weren't for his girly-man choices thus far in his career he would be a full blown movie right now. But alas, he doesn't really do movies that involve him shooting a gun and hence the fact that most Americans don't know him. But hopefully people will see him here and when they do they will enjoy themselves with this light weight yet engrossing film. ***1/4

reviewText: What starts off as a decent legal thriller with all Anthony Hopkins has to offer being portrayed on screen outsmarting an idiot of a prosecutor ends in the most unsatisfying way imaginable. Everything works exactly as Hopkins plans, until the mind-bogglingly bad ending that fails on a multitude of levels. First of all, the "evidence" the prosecutor obtains would never, ever, EVER be allowed in court. It would be so illegal as to make Hopkins look even more not guilty with a simple denial that the prosecutor is correct at such a useless and circumstantial claim. The prosecutor, in a frenzy of idiocy, visits Hopkins in his own home (this alone is bad enough, but it gets far worse) for a confession. Not only is what Hopkins' alleged slip-up not admissible in court in any form, but what he forces from him for a crime *that he did not commit* is a public confession out of nothing but boasting, but even then, the hero would lose here in the real world. The prosecutor does absolutely nothing for his case the entire way through, and the legal system is shot in the head just as badly as the victim in the whole case. Basic legal rules are completely ignored, the "twist" ending is insensible, stupid, and impossible, and everything is just ruined completely by it. Hopkins would win this if the movie played by the rules, but it doesn't when it means the most, making the whole thing totally pointless.To make everything infinitely worse, the Double Jeopardy rule that Hopkins takes advantage of is not disproven like the prosecutor says. Hero Prosecutor gets around the Double Jeopardy rule with a charge that would never hold up, because the fact is, he didn't do what the prosecutor said he did. He did not directly cause his wife's death, so everything used to charge him with murder is simply false. He's charged with one thing, found innocent, and then the prosecutor "turns the tables" and finds him guilty of a more serious crime--one he actually didn't do, so he could get around the Double Jeopardy rule.It gets even worse. The Double Jeopardy rule isn't even used correctly here. Double Jeopardy doesn't simply mean you can't be charged for the same crime twice. The twist here is that Hopkins is charged and tried with one thing, and then again with another. But the two crimes he's charged with could not be treated as separate crimes, even if it were the case that he were guilty of the second that he gets caught on.And yes, it gets even worse than that. When Hopkins' wife ultimately dies, it's *through legal means*. This is where everything falls so far apart, the title starts to make sense in the context of the story. When he's doing his thing, what he's doing is legal. He has legal free reign over whether or not they maintain life support. He didn't do anything illegal when he asks them to pull the plug. There is no murder charge possible here. He has every right to do what he did, whether or not people agree with it. No illegal action was taking place--Hopkins, at that point, is a free man, with no charges against him. Just because he tells a doctor to pull the plug on his wife doesn't make him a murderer in any way. He did not cause her death, and even if he did, it was legal. reviewText: "Primal Fear" director, Gregory Hoblit's legal cat and mouse game between veteran actor Anthony Hopkins and promising newcomer Ryan Gosling could have been a psychological thriller of Hitchcockian proportions, but to many fissures in either the editing phase or the overall concept make this "Fracture" borderline abysmal.Like a kaleidoscope, all the elements exist and combine to create a shimmering bent-ray look into the perfect crime.  From the onset, the audience comprehends fully that Crawford (Hopkins) killed his adulterous wife and somehow perhaps because in this role Hopkins perfects and tempers with a knowing sadness that familiar megalomaniacal ingeniousness spawned during his Academy Award winning enactment of Hannibal Lector we empathize with Pavlovian fascination, wishing with all of our might that Crawford beats the rap in spite of the wrongness of his transgression.If Hannibal Lector suggests the sophisticated power of a warped mind, the character of Crawford explores similar territory.  In Hopkins deft hands, Crawford smolders with nuance that begs to be investigated.  We know Crawford is riddled with fractures---fractures from his childhood, his adult past and his obviously failed marriage.  The incidentals need not be detailed; the beauty of Hopkin's performance makes disclosure unnecessary.Like Lector, Crawford simply is and he's got the high-dollar items to back up and accentuate his success on various mind and achievement levels.  As head of his own aerodynamics company, his organized mind can see and arrange the components of his life from the perspective of a higher vantage point--- his accoutrements illicit an affluent privacy: he lives in a gate-contained cushy California crib, drives a fantastic sports car, tinkers with magnificent Rube Goldberg contraptions (kudos to Dutch artist Mark Bischoff) and possesses an off-the-chart IQ for which any Mensa might, well, kill.  Unfortunately, one of his acquisitions isn't going along with the program; wife Jennifer has set up house with her police inspector boyfriend.  Within the first five minutes of the film, Crawford takes care of this blot on his brand of perfection with a quick bullet to her brain, rendering her comatose.Enter the perfect rub, public defender-protagonist, Willy Beachum (Ryan Gosling).  Young and hungry, Will is about to shun his inbred liberal/Democrat/socialistic values and embrace "the dark side"---accepting a position with a posh-y firm the type of which caused Will Shakespeare to utter in Henry VI, "Let's kill all the lawyers."  Older and wiser Crawford immediately sizes up his competition as being distracted by his imminent career transition and the open and shut case that the DA expects disintegrates into an entertaining farce where Crawford maintains the upper hand with a most sadistic yet unassuming calmness that belies the partial deadness of the soul beneath. Gosling needs to regroup fast before he puts a permanent blot on his win-only record and blows his chances for his greed driven dreams.The script's overall concentration on Gosling's character unfortunately falls prey to many of Hollywood's formulaic pitfalls.  Hoblit should have emulated great suspense thrillers like "Deathtrap" or "Sleuth" and left out characters that do little to enhance the plot.  In this instance, ice blonde Rosamund Pike as Gosling's new boss becomes merely an ornament decorating Gosling's roguish manliness rather than a personality important to driving the plot.  Her family reiterates the socialist message while they sip expensive wine during Thanksgiving dinner that anyone with a mindset slightly akin to "Wall Street's" Gordon Gekko condones and enables Big Corporate Evil.  But none of that has anything to do with the intricate mind game that could have been played and relished by the two main characters.Likewise the plot's loose ends eventually tarnish the film's trite outcome.  I suppose the concentration on the poorly constructed subplots distracts the audience from fully analyzing some of the hints, snafus and gaffs but do not create enough background noise to stop one from realizing that the lover's compromising of the evidence on the Crawford property and at the crime lab would have provided Crawford with yet another interesting gambit to play.Bottom line:  In true Hollywood fashion, the film's ultimate significance lies in some unwanted political message about big business versus social awareness rather than the ultimate mind game that it purports to be.  The film entertains and generates conversation, but its structural fractures downplay the interplay between minds that this reviewer would have found much more satisfying.Diana Faillace Von Behren"reneofc"

reviewText: There's a familiar bag of tricks at work in this 2007 courtroom-driven suspense thriller, and it goes beyond Anthony Hopkins' deliberate echo of Hannibal Lecter in his malevolently amusing performance as Ted Crawford, a wealthy and cuckolded industrial engineer. It involves the intricately plotted, marginally credible screenplay by Daniel Pyne and Glenn Gers, which reminds me of an old episode ofColumbo. That's not necessarily a bad thing since those Sunday night shows could be entertaining whodunits, but the derivative veneer of this movie purposefully shortchanges logic for contrived twists. In fact, the central conceit of the film is that we know Crawford shot his beautiful, adulterous wife point blank. The story is really about how he plans to get away with it and how young Willie Beachum, an ambitious and unflagging assistant D.A. bucks the odds and seeks the truth in this case.Giving away any more is unnecessary, as director Gregory Hoblit is no stranger to the courtroom giving us the equally twist-infestedPrimal Feareleven years ago. While the twists are not as pronounced here, they also don't feel as hard-earned primarily because Crawford and Beachum feel more like movie archetypes than flesh-and-blood characters. This is where casting helps considerably since Hopkins can easily evince menace with minimal effort - a blank stare, veiled smirk, the delusion of befuddlement in the courtroom - before you can sayThe Silence of the Lambs. Impressive in last year'sHalf Nelson, Ryan Gosling plays Beachum in a likeably braggadocio manner with a heavy Southern accent and a variety of idiosyncratic tics. It is his character that goes through something of an arc from accepting a high-paying job at an exclusive private firm to a personal catharsis over his crusade for justice.The two principal actors are well matched in their scenes together, even though one is a virtual replay of the one between Hopkins and Jodie Foster inLambs. The rest of the actors aren't given much leeway to provide any meaningful depth to their characters - David Strathairn, in a complete role reversal from this year'sBourne Ultimatum, as Beachum's moral conscience and current boss, D.A. Joe Labruto; Billy Burke particularly lackluster as the indiscreet detective caught in the middle; Embeth Davidtz making her precious few moments count as Crawford's dissatisfied wife Jennifer; and former Bond girl Rosamund Pike as Nikki Gardner, Beachum's boss at his new firm. Her romantic relationship with Beachum seems like a particularly absurd plot convenience given the impropriety of a senior partner bedding an associate.The twisty ending satisfies for the obvious reason but is tethered in legal precedents that seem strangely arbitrary (pardon the pun). As part of its set of extras, the 2007 DVD contains two alternatives to the final ending, both making the inevitable a more Baroque-level experience that borders on silly. The other deleted scenes are of marginal interest including two extended variations on the romantic coupling between Gardner and Beachum. While a trailer is included, there is surprisingly no commentary track from either the director or the two principals. For what it's worth, the film is a fun ride for the undemanding because a moment's thought afterward will inevitably spoil your memory of it.
summary: Overly Tricky Plot Makes for Glib Entertainment Thanks Mainly to the Two Leads

reviewText: Since I am both a lover of psychological thrillers and a fan of Anthony Hopkins and Ryan Gosling, it would be nearly impossible for me not to like this film, Fracture. And I was not disappointed. Though I would agree with some of the reviewers that Ryan's character Willy Beachum was not particularly likeable at first, I would disagree that he was as bad as Anthony's character, Ted Crawford. After all, Willy is cocky and ambitious, Ted is arrogant AND a cold-blooded killer. Willy though flippant, and perhaps a little arrogant, hardly comes off as someone who would shoot their wife point-blank in the face.Ted's machinations occur from the beginning. In the very first scene, he tells his wife, "I love you," and in the next minute shoots her in the face. And every step he takes after that is carefully designed to outwit everyone from the cops to the prosecutor to even the judge. It's this maneuvering by Ted that makes the film worth seeing. Everybody knows he did it -- but is he that smart, that conniving that he will get away with the perfect murder?That's where Willy comes in. From the beginning, he underestimates Ted. Pre-occupied with starting a new, lucrative job, Willy thinks he has an open and shut case and gives it very little attention. In fact, when he first visits the crime scene with the police, he is on the phone with his soon-to-be employer trying to decide how he wants his new office decorated. Well, he gets totally humiliated at the trial by Ted and things go downhill from there.The movie, though not heart-pounding, keeps your interest. Noteworthy performances are given by the rest of the cast. David Strathairn plays Willy's boss, the hard-boiled, but with soft edges, head of the district attorney office. Embeth Davidtz' talent is wasted as the wife, as she is comatose for most of the movie. Rosamund Pike plays a ruthless lawyer and Willy's brief love interest. Pike actually is more dislikeable than Willy as she embodies all the things we hate about lawyers. In one scene she chastises Willy that it's not about convicting a killer, but it's more important that you "can do as you're told."The most unbelievable character I think was the police officer (Billy Burke) who had an affair with Ted's wife which precipitates the whole chain of events. He comes off as a lovesick dolt. What cop would have an affair with a woman and not know her real name? He, more than anyone,  has the resources to find out someone's identity. But for the plot to work, perhaps him not knowing her name is essential and I guess we can forgive the movie this test of our common sense.The movie has good character development -- at least for Willy. He goes from a flippant, all-about-me persona to someone who actually cares about the victim and bringing her assaulter to justice. The plot may be somewhat predictable, but the main method Ted uses to get away with the crime was a surprise to me. The dialogue is good, especially Ted whose every word is calculating and clever. Throughout the movie, he taunts everyone with his superior cleverness but eventually forgets his own earlier message to Willy.The title "Fracture" is the movie's subtle message. Early on, Ted makes a comment that, "If you look closely enough, you'll find that everything has a weak spot where it can break." And that's what Ted is good at throughout the movie, finding people's weak spot and using it to his advantage. But what Ted doesn't seem to comprehend, is that he too has a weak spot and it will be his undoing, his fatal flaw.
summary: Nearly Impossible For Me Not To Like This Film

reviewText: **No Spoilers**Is there such a thing as a perfect crime? Perhaps, but Fracture is far from it. Basically, we are dealing with a romantic crime drama that turns into a Court TV/TLC Channel Forensic Science episode, until the cliché ending. We still don't understand why Fracture is being praised by so many critics when the real fractures are its obvious flaws--editing, draggy moments, awkward dialogue and the "what were they thinking" grand finale. Despite the respectable performance by Hopkins and the eye candy cinematography, the film drags forever and it's not as clever as it appears to be.Story:The meticulous (and very rich) structural engineer Ted Crawford (Anthony Hopkins) knows very well that his beautiful wife Jennifer (Embeth Davidtz) is having an affair--obviously with a younger fellow. He wastes no time and once they are alone in their house, he shoots her right in the face. Police arrest him for attempted murder--she is still alive, but unfortunately in a coma.The cocky young attorney Willy Beachum (Ryan Gosling) has been assigned to be the prosecutor against Ted who confessed his crime, right at the scene, to the negotiator Detective Rob Nunally (Billy Burke)--who is the only man that heard his confession and also Jennifer's lover. Willy thinks that his case--because the confession and all--is an easy one and shouldn't take long to close it and he doesn't know that Rob was seeing Jennifer. Our young lawyer is also about to get a high-paid job for a bigger firm--his new boss will be the sexy Nikki Gardner (Rosamund Pike). Willy and anybody else for that matter don't know that Ted is not your regular jealous old husband, but a smart and dangerous man who knows the law very well and it will use it to his advantage. As the story progresses, things get complicated for Willy who cannot find any hard evidence against Ted--Willy's career and personal life are also in jeopardy.Review:Fracture opens up pretty much a la Basic Instinct--the slick cinematography along with the love scenes--but there is no build up or character development before the shooting incident. We just see Ted planning his fatal crime in a very generic way. After he tried to kill his wife and goes to jail, then the film turns into a long version of the TV show Law & Order where nothing is what it seems with the traditional mumbo jumbo lawyer talk. At this point, the movie revolves mostly on Willy's motives and personal life. The proud lawyer who finally found a case that he really cares about. He wants to do the right thing, but his situation is so desperate that at one point, he wants to bring down the engineer at any cost even if he has to lie or loose his new job. While in Jail, Ted enjoys all of this and plays silly mind games with Willy. The chemistry between these two actors is very little. Predictably, the star of the film is Hopkins who gives us a decent performance as the evil cold blooded man who wanted to get even with his wife--not hard from him because he often plays these kinds of roles.Director Gregory Hoblit needs to know what this is not a TV movie. His experience in the small screen is painfully obvious--visually pretty, but TV-like nevertheless. The movie drags for most the film--we get unnecessary scenes like a Thanksgiving dinner where the dialogue is preposterous. Not only that, the worst part is towards the end of the film. They portray Ted as the smartest man in the courtroom, but the cliché ending makes you think twice about his intelligence.The Verdict:Too long to be a Law & Order episode and too boring to be the next Basic Instinct, Fracture deals with an angry senior citizen who cannot stand his unfaithful wife and decides to kill her. Perhaps there is a fracture in our legal system and the movie tries to show that anyone with knowledge of the law can get around it. Whatever they writers wanted, those draggy moments and cliché ending ruins all of the other good aspects of the film.
summary: Too long to be a Law & Order episode and too boring to be the next Basic Instinct

reviewText: Crime scene investigation takes a black eye in this thriller. Although the movie is excellent and is a study of personality flaws in overly successful yuppies it is nonetheless a bit of a scam when it comes to evidence linking a criminal with a potential murder.Physical evidence is good but is not absolutely the only requirement to convict in our system of justice. Indeed, I have witnessed murderers go to jail without any physical evidence presented. So we are somewhat mislead here in this picture. Also, although not generally known, all guns have identification numbers and in situations that are present here in the movie the officers would certainly know if their guns had been tampered in any way.The relations of officers are also known, especially in their off duty amorous affairs by their co-workers and the chance that an investigator would show up at the scene and not reveal his relationship in a situation to a superior is highly unlikely.Yet, this film is still tense and interesting despite all the police procedural flaws. Anthony Hopkins is at his Hannibal best and sinks his teeth into a young strapping successful professional prosecutor who believes he is God's gift to women and the best brain to ever come into the DA's office. We love to see Hopkins manipulate the smart aleck prosecutor, playing on his vanity and then skillfully destroy the young mans reputation before all of Los Angeles. Wonderful!The movie is definitely worth a view and may require you to view it more than once to understand all that is going on. It is up there with the Illusionist, A Beautiful Mind and The Sixth Sense and Croupier in the plotting and it is certainly quite an entertaining movie.

Crawford moves some things in the house including the shell casings (replacing them with new ones) and waits for the police to come.When the police arrive Crawford confesses to his crime and then surrenders. At his arraignment Crawford retracts his confession and then says that he wants to represent himself. He then meets Willy Beachum (Ryan Gosling) who is the district attorney trying to put him away. Beachum has some trouble, he is a young attorney who has not lost a case and is receiving a new and well paid job at a new firm for it. He expected Crawfords case to be very easy but Crawford has so many tricks up his sleeve and Beachum might not get that job. The two go back and forth trying to outsmart one another but it will all come down to the wire and the end is pretty darn good.The story is a good one and with characters that could bore you being played by any other actor the cast was picked very well. In a lot of movies they feel the need to add a girlfriend or boyfriend to fill some movie time and it doesn't always work. What makes this film is Anthony Hopkins, he does a crazy job playing this guy and he makes every minute of the movie a little more interesting. He waited for the police to arrive where he admitted to murdering his wife.It turned out that the wife didn't die.  However, she's left in a vegetative state in a hospital.Gosling plays Beachum, an up-and-coming lawyer with a 97% winning rate, who is soon transferring from the D.A.'s office to a prestigious law firm.  Before transferring, Beachum hears about this case involving Crawford.  He believes that this is a simple open-and-shut case.However, Crawford masterminded all of this from the beginning.  As soon as Beachum takes this case, it goes downhill. The confession is no good as Crawford, representing himself in court, points out that the detective who took his confession is the man whom his wife was having an affair with.From there, you think that the story plot would build up to a bigger climax.  Alas, it doesn't.  So, now, you're left guessing, for the rest of the movie, who will win at the end.  The cat?  Or the mouse?

reviewText: I was trying to answer a question about what movies I'd seen recently.  When I said I'd seen "Fracture," my mind went blank; and I couldn't remember who was in it or what it was about.  I decided that if I reviewed it, maybe it'd come back to me.  The title and the film seem disconnected to me.  I'm sure there was a connection between the word "Fracture" and the picture, but it sounds like something Hitchcock would have directed.  Now "Shot in the Head" might have brought back what Ted Crawford does to his wife Jennifer.Director Gregory Hoblit made a name for himself as the Executive Producer of the TV series "NYPD Blue."  He directs this stylish thriller that has the suspense of a chess match, brainy but not that interesting to watch.Anthony Hopkin will probably always be identified with his amazing Oscar-winning performance from "Silence of the Lambs."  So many of his characters seem like variations on that spooky character.  Ryan Gosling was a great rebel romantic in "The Notebook" and received an Oscar nomination for "Half Nelson" last year, which I know at least 24 people have seen.  As DA Willy Beachum, he's too flawed to be entirely likeable, but one does admire the character's perseverance.  Embeth Davidtz plays Crawford's wife Jennifer in a brief appearance.  Her role in the small film "Junebug" was filled with energy.  Her face is one that leaves you trying to recall where you'd seen it.  While I couldn't come up with "Bridget Jones Diary" or "Schindler's List" anymore than I could recall the movie "Fracture" when asked, she does a nice job as the wife of the wealthy but cold Ted Crawford.  One really can't blame her for seeking out police negotiator Rob Nunnally played by Billy Burke, who I did recognize from one of my favorite episodes of TV's "Monk."  Burke does a good job of playing the distraught lover, although one wonders how one used to being in the middle of crisis events suddenly loses it on the courtroom steps.  David Strathairn turns in another amazingly tightly controlled performance that is well suited to this film, brainy but boring, or "Good Night & Good Luck."My favorite part of the film was Rosamund Pike as high-powered lawyer Nikki Gardener.  Hoblit takes us to the Gardner family's home for Thanksgiving, which introduces us to her father, a judge, but also allows Pike to show numerous levels between the professional and the personal family life.  Her face is familiar from double-o-seven's "Die Another Day," "Pride & the Prejudice" and "The Libertine."  [I think was one of the 24 people who actually watched "The Libertine" all the way to the end!]"Fracture" really fractured for me at the end.  Without giving any spoiler, it seemed that someone as bright as Ted Crawford would surely be able to have contemplated the lame-brained technicality with which Beachum wraps up the plot & assures us that good guys win.  While there is a lot to be said for sitting in a cool movie theatre in the summertime watching a good movie, odds are a year from now you'll also be trying to remember, "What was that about?"  Taxi!

reviewText: Ted Crawford (Anthony Hopkins) is a smart man.  A very smart man.  In his spare time, for instance, he constructs elaborately gold and silver contraptions that send crystal marbles on endless, dizzying loops, around and over and under and back up, the cogs and wheels turning inexplicably, inconceivably, pointlessly.  These devices are beautiful and fun to look at -- one of them towering almost four feet high -- but they are ultimately useless.  They don't do much other than divert, and even that in small measure."Fracture," a courtroom thriller from the same guy who madeFallenandPrimal Fear(Gregory Hoblit) wants to be as smart and intricate as those marble roller coasters, but it is only as diverting.The set-up is interesting (and Hoblit's detail-driven directing make even the splashes of water on Hopkins' face look luxurious): Crawford comes home early one day and shoots his adulterous wife in the face.  Several hours later, he has been arrested.  Signed and verbal confession.  Murder weapon in hand.The open-and-shut case is handed down to a clever-n-clean-cut Willy Beachum (Ryan Gosling), an attorney on the way up to bigger, brassier waters, about to start work at a prestigious nickel-and-iron law firm, moving on from his down-home grass-roots spot at a small legal house where his prowess is not-so-subtly resented by everyone but the cute-as-a-button secretaries.  One last quick case, thinks Beachum, before he packs his bags and starts working for the Big Dogs.Of course, it's not so simple as all that.  It turns out that most of the evidence is inadmissable because the arresting officer, Rob Nunally (Billy Burke) also happens to be Crawford's wife's lover.  As the locks on the case begin to disintegrate, so does Beachum's handle on his career, notwithstanding the brief (and weirdly directed) affair Beachum begins to have with his soon-to-be boss, Nikki Gardner (Rosamund Pike playing every upwardly-mobile, take-no-guff female attorney that's ever come out of Central Casting).The linchpin of the case -- and of the entire movie -- rests on finding the murder weapon.  Everything else is background noise.  The problem is, the script makes it pretty obvious where the weapon is.  We can see where that marble is going just by tracing the gold-plated track, so the destination is no surprise at all.  And since the entire story -- quite honestly, the entire story -- swivels on the fulcrum of that supposed tension (up to the excruciatingly slow revelation that Beachum has at the end), the entire story fails.I'd give points for Hoblit's competent directing and even for the acting.  Hopkins and Gosling are both powerhouses, one well-established, the other proving his mettle with every new film, but the lines they say are old, the "twists" they tread are so old, they've been worn into a rut by countless movies before them.  And their conflict -- the brash, young upstart (a brilliant man, really) versus the wise, studied maestro (an equally brilliant man) -- doesn't get much play time.  Even when it is on-screen, it's a mostly uninteresting battle of egos.Very little is at stake in "Fracture," and even less is worth noting, and it's all because of the plot.  Fine acting and decent filming are like well-sculpted mahogany frames and gentle ogee pathways in an over-large marble maze-way.  They look pretty, they move just as prettily, but after five minutes, it gets old to watch.  The truth is, this story wasn't nearly as smart as Crawford's over-indulgent clock-work toys; I would've prefered to spend an hour watching them instead.

reviewText: This is an enjoyable enough thriller - has that `seen it before' vibe, but raised above the level of the plethora of similar movies by its star performances and glossy veneer.Plot wise, the obligatory twist in the standard murder investigation is that we see right off that Anthony Hopkins murders his wife.  The rub comes, when he looks like he might get away with it, and the only thing between him and freedom is a young up-and-coming public prosecutor, played by Ryan Gosling.  He is starting a new job for a new boss (Rosamund Pike, from Die Another Day - much sexier here) in a high profile corporate law firm.  So for him it becomes a question of conscience - can he let the murderer go, so that he can move on with his new career, or will he jeapordise his new career to do whatever it takes to `bring him down'.So things are set up less as a whodunit, but more as a Columbo episode format.  We know he did it - but will the good guy figure it out?  None of the scenes have too much in the way of surprises, and the twists are fairly well flagged.  So what we are left with is a very glossy looking thriller with superior performances.  Sure, Hopkins has had better moments, and could be accused of sleepwalking through the movie, but Hopkins on autopilot is still better than the rest of the pack.  And the big surprise is Ryan Gosling - here, he puts in a memorable central performance.  The movie hinges on our buying into this character, and Gosling pulls it off.  It's Gosling that raises this to a 4 star movie.It's clear the plot set up will never be entirely satisfactorily resolved, as evidenced by the two alternative endings where they played with how best to finish the story off.  In the end, they chose the best option, even if it does feel somewhat anticlimactic.  The other deleted scenes add little to proceedings.All in all, despite a gnawing sense of familiarity, this works well, thanks in large part to the strong cast.

reviewText: "Even a broken clock is right, twice a day."  Such are the zingers that Ted Crawford (Anthony Hopkins) tosses at Willy Beachum, very young deputy D.A.  This movie is a brilliant psychological thriller.  Ted is convinced that he has executed the perfect crime.  He readily confesses to shooting his wife, who he has caught in an affair. He is convinced his confession will be thrown out on technicalities.  He is so convinced that he even attempts to serve as his own counsel for the trial.  The person that he has caught his wife with adds even more intrigue to the movie, and he makes sure the person is there when the body is discovered so that he can see the look of anguish on the guy's face.  The wife is not dead, however, and on life support in a coma.  The young prosecutor knows he is losing badly and spends hours at her bedside hoping to revive her so she can name the shooter.  Ted loves the game of cat and mouse with the young attorney, and feels that Willy is so cocky, he will trap himself up.  The finale of the movie is worth the wait.  Ted is so diabolically clever at every turn, covering all of the bases, but there are two little details he has forgotten.  One concerns the double jeaopardy clause, and the other is in underestimating Willy's abilities.  The movie is wonderful, but even more enjoyable with some fava beans and a little Chianti.

Hopkins has a few tricks up his sleeve, and the prosecutor (Gosling) is so intrigued by the case that he postpones his new job at a prestigious defense firm to stay and try Hopkins. reviewText: I first saw this movie on HBO, and while I was glad I didn't pay money in a theater to see it, I still don't think it's the biggest waste of movie time ever. (I'm still trying to get back the 90 minutes of my life I lost to "The Forgotten," though I long since made Time-Warner refund me the $3.99 charge for its rental.) Initially I would have given Fracture 2 stars, but once I started thinking of Willie as a young Jack McCoy of Law and Order I decided it was really more of a 3, almost a 3.5 star movie.This movie had nothing to do with Jack McCoy or Law and Order, I just felt like it should have.  Other reviewers said they would have been more accepting of this as a TV movie, and I came to agree. It would have been the perfect NBC Sunday night movie about how Jack McCoy of Law and Order came to be who he is.It should have been a better movie; the writing, directing and acting could all have been better.  Hopkins is adept in his role as the intelligent and manipulative psychopath. Backhandedly overbearing, he subtly insults even while playing disarmingly nave, dropping  hints to people that he is smarter than and a few steps ahead of them. Gosling is convincing as the cocky, overconfident young man. Typically he is not easily fooled and fairly unflappable, as certain of his success in the bedroom as the courtroom, but Gosling played his role with a bit too much of the "it's all good" attitude. He wasn't very convincing in scenes that were supposed to display urgency or intensity, not in the courtroom or out of it. There also wasn't much chemistry between him and Nikki, his new boss and romantic interest. That she was his new boss with whom he immediately gets involved with, and given that it was a job he got with an off hand legal stunt and still had to prove himself at should have made their affair feel more risqué, but didn't.  I generally couldn't feel the heat of his anger, frustration, or even lust. This could also have due to poor writing, directing, and maybe even casting. He did have one really good scene with one of the detectives, the one played by Cliff Curtis, where they were both frustrated with events and each other and played it well, so I couldn't be sure he couldn't deliver more emotional intensity if the movie had been better written and directed. Unfortunately the parts where tension and suspense were supposed to be building generally fell flat.Now if it had been about Jack McCoy, Lobruto could have been Adam Schiff, making the scenes between them more emotionally charged, particularly the one where Willie says "that's what this is about, I'm not going to be you in 20 years" to Lobruto. Lobruto knows Willie better than Willie knows himself and seems to be able to mentor him in the same way Adam Schiff might have mentored a young Jack McCoy.  Fracture wasn't made for the Law and Order franchise, unfortunately.As far as the DVD extras, there wasn't that much, but there are a lot of better movies with fewer DVD extras. Deleted scenes and alternate endings were included. They were interesting to see but better left out of the movie, in my opinion. There was no commentary track though and that seemed like sour grapes to me.This is the story of a confident young lawyer that knows how to win and remain ethical, (even if he's riding the line ethically) but learns how to care. It's neither the best nor worst movie you'll ever see. I went ahead and got it from Amazon market place because I would have gotten it from the $5.50 bin at Wal-Mart, I just don't feel like waiting for it to get there.

reviewText: Anthony Hopkins loves movies where he can wipe the floor with his costars. He is almost giddy in roles like Hannibal Lector. His character in director Gregory Hoblit's latest thriller, Fracture, is no different. Like the eggshell analogy that Hopkins makes to his costar Ryan Gosling, Fracture falls prey to the same smarmy advice the star gives out: everything, no matter how perfect it may look, has a flaw.When wealthy and intelligent aerodynamics expert Ted Crawford (Hopkins) catches his wife in an act of infidelity with a Los Angeles homicide detective, he cooks up an elaborate plan to not only kill his wife, but to legally get away with it. What should have been an open and shut case for District Attorney Willy Beachum turns into a career ending nightmare as Crawford seemingly outsmarts the law at every turn.Though the direction, acting and visual style in Fracture is fantastic, the hairline crack that splinters the picture is the film's attempt at creating suspense by relying on a twist ending that is easily predictable given the information that is presented early in the film. How exactly does Crawford shoot his wife in the face with a weapon that has never been fired? Given the revealing marketing for the film, which gives away the circumstances surrounding the murder, audiences can easily trace the steps that Hopkins takes early in the film, clearly giving them an idea of where Fracture is going.In the best thrillers, when the inevitable twist hits, it is the little clues scattered throughout the picture which give the ending credibility. While all these details are within Fracture, they are so clear that if you don't see the crack in the villain's flawless plan immediately, you will be kicking yourself when the film finally presents it to you.That being said, how does Fracture manage to hold the audience's attention despite its blatant reveal of the picture's number one mystery? While a less experienced director might rely heavily on this twist alone, Gregory Hoblit manages to see through what could have been a thinly veiled, plot driven movie and finds an intriguing character study.While Hopkins chews up the scenery with his vast intellect and charming whit, Fracture is really the story of Willy Beachum. Considering the fact that Fracture consists of a cast which includes an Academy Award winner and two nominees, it was to be expected that Hoblit should have no problem drawing performances from his actors. The real surprise in Fracture is just how well planned out the story of Willy Beachum was.Ryan Gosling's character begins the film as an arrogant, hot shot district attorney who has been put on the fast track, landing a job in the private sector. Thinking that Crawford's case will be the last in his short tenure serving the public, Beachum shrugs off what appears to be an easy win. His refusal to take the case seriously, combined with Crawford's meticulous planning, ultimately leads to Beachum's downfall. With his cushy job in jeopardy, Beachum's character develops a methodical obsession with Crawford, searching desperately to find the one clue that will put his nemesis away for good.As the film progresses Gosling's character changes from cocky to heroic. At first it is fun to see Hopkins toy with him, but thanks to Gosling's surprisingly good acting and Hoblit's taught direction, as Beachum changes, so does the audience's expectations. We want Gosling to come out on top. This change, from selfishness to selflessness is what gives his character the roundness that carries Fracture past its faults.Though predictable, it is the dramatic arc of Willy Beachum which separates Fracture from just another episode of Law and Order. While Hopkins' character begins the film as a smarmy antihero, he essentially pushes Beachum into becoming the unlikely champion of the story, and in some ways Fracture showcases one legendary actor passing on the torch to another.-Joe Russo

reviewText: "Fracture", the new film from director Gregory Hoblit ("Primal Fear", TV's "L.A. Law", "NYPD Blue"), is a pretty routine legal thriller with four attributes that help it stand out from the rest of the pack.Ted Crawford (Anthony Hopkins), an aerospace tycoon, sits at his desk working on a new Rube Goldberg contraption when he suddenly realizes he should leave the office. He shows up at a local hotel and finds his wife, Jennifer (Embeth Davidtz) having an affair with Rob (Billy Burke, "Ladder 49", TV's "24"), a detective with the Los Angeles police force. When Jennifer returns home, Ted confronts her and shoots her. Later, Rob is the detective called to the scene. When he realizes his girlfriend has been killed, he attacks Ted. At trial, Willy Beachum (Ryan Gosling, "Half Nelson), a deputy DA with one foot out the door for a private practice job, is reluctant to take the case until he learns there is a signed confession. He convinces the district attorney (David Strathairn) that he can close the case in the two weeks he has left, keeping his conviction rate and new job intact. Willie, a man with a lot of debt, anxious to get going on his new high salary position, takes the case and soon meets his new boss, Nikki Gardner (Rosamunde Pike, "Pride and Prejudice", "Die Another Day"), who seems to be attracted to her new Junior Associate. But Willie is cocky and assumes this is a slam-dunk until he starts to learn Ted's strategies to win the trial."Fracture" is a pretty routine legal thriller centered on a `brilliant mind' who will manipulate everyone around him in an effort to go free. The one person standing in his way? A younger `brilliant mind'.There are four factors that set "Fracture" apart from the rest of the pack. The first, and least significant of the four, are Hoblit's efforts to shoot this film in a very lush style, making it an almost beautiful film to watch. Hoblit worked on many of Steven Bocho's television series and the style is similar to "L.A. Law" or "Murder One". All of the surfaces gleam with polish, shadows are heavy and dark, and figures are frequently seen from behind screens or in shadow. Sunlight also seems to play a major influence on all of the cinematography. Often, characters are walking through hallways and we see the glow of early afternoon light trying to break through the dusty passageways or reflecting off marble surfaces. This technique helps to give the film a rich look, even beyond the general lifestyle of Hopkin's character, who is rich and lives in a nice, modern house. This technique helps to give Gosling's office at the District Attorney's office a rich look, even though the office is cramped, unglamorous and very different from Ted's lifestyle.The other three factors are the talent of three actors involved in the film. First and foremost is Anthony Hopkins. Hopkins has played this type of role before, the brilliant mastermind, but he does it so well. There are and will be inevitable comparisons between this role and Hannibal Lecter (both are brilliant, both are deadly, both play mind games with a young `protégé') and Ted Crawford is Hannibal - light. But it is always interesting to watch a master like Hopkins, even when he is lobbed a softball like this role. Crawford, an aeronautical engineer, likes to create elaborate rube Goldberg contraptions, with long metal chutes, allowing Crawford to place a metal ball at the top and watch it move through a series of passages, all connected, much like a large version of the game "Mousetrap". When he realizes his wife is cheating on him, he decides to shoot her and comes up with a way to get through all of the legal challenges and hurdles. Presumably, studying these contraptions helps him work through all of the possible variations.As the story progresses, Hopkins manages to add some nice touches to the role, making him seem even more devious and menacing. During a character's testimony, Crawford, who has chosen to represent himself, doodles on a yellow legal pad, periodically ripping the pages from the pad. Each time he tears off a sheet, the sound reverberates through the quiet courtroom, causing Beachum to turn his attention to the defendant.Ryan Gosling does a great job as Willie Beachum, the Assistant District Attorney who gladly accepts a high paying job at one of the most respected law firms in Los Angeles. Beachum is cocky and trying to move beyond his roots; he grew up poor in Oklahoma and now has a load of debt from law school. He clearly always saw the District Attorney's office as a stepping-stone and is now glad to be leaving it. When he meets with his boss (played by David Strathairn), a comment is made about Willie's high conviction rate and the lengths he would go to get it. Willie is a complicated guy and not beyond inflating the truth or maneuvering things to benefit his goals.When he meets his new boss, Nikki Gardner (Rosamunde Pike), he is instantly attracted to her and they flirt. This is yet another example of his cockiness, because he knows he is good looking and doesn't care if he flirts with his new boss. The fact that this leads to the film's biggest plot hole is beyond the point. because he is so brazen about it, this adds significantly to his character.He strides into the courtroom and decides to prosecute Ted's case, despite his impending new job, because he considers it a slam-dunk. Ted signed a confession, there was no one else in the house, and how could he lose? Then, Ted begins to pull the strings and manipulate everything and everyone.To a lesser extent, David Strathairn adds significance as District Attorney Lobruto, Willie's boss. From the moment Lobruto walks into Beachum's office to confront him, we see that Lobruto has world-weariness to him. As an elected public official, he is aware of what little he can accomplish and accepts everything else with ease. He has been beaten down by the system and takes his young Assistant DA's defection with the slightest disgruntlement. But he understands. If he had the same chance, he would probably take it.Embeth Davidtz, Rosamunde Pike, Billy Burke, Bob Gunton and Fiona Shaw all play supporting characters, some with greater success and greater impact, but they all add to the texture of the story, making it interesting to watch."Fracture" is not a great film, but it is fun to watch all of the twists and turns, the machinations Hopkins' character puts everyone through. For it to be a great film, Hopkins would have to add something different to his character. Is it just me or does it seem odd that Crawford is playing mind games with a poor guy from the South, who came from a questionable background? Does Beachum's background sound familiar to anyone else? Did they ask Jodie Foster to take the role before she refused it because it was too similar to Clarice Starling? Gosling does a good job with the role, but Hopkins is such a great actor and this role is not a stretch that it seems like a disappointment.

reviewText: Fractured describes the tone of this suspense thriller. Playing like a cross of "Primal Fear" and "Silence of the Lambs", "Fracture" isn't as good as either one of those films but the performances by Anthony Hopkins and Ryan Gosling do raise this 2 star thriller to 3 stars. The film works best when these two advesaries face off against each other. The director Gregory Hoblit ("Fallen", "Frequency"...seems this guy has a things for titles with an f in them)and the writers Daniel Pyne ("The Sum of All Fears")Glenn Gers ("Cybill")squander the film's potential by laying out the story in a linear straight forward fashion. As a result, there's no surprises except for a slight twist at the end of the film. The film lives up to a line that Hopkins says in the film--"Even a broken clock is right twice a day". This broken thriller could have been right more often if the storytelling had been more skillful.SPOILERS**Ted Crawford (Anthony Hopkins) is a wealthy aviation designer. When he finds that his wife (Embeth Davison who is completely wasted in her role) is having an affair he makes a decision to kill her and he has a plan to get away with it. When Crawford butts heads with district attorney Willy Beachum it seems like a perfect case for both of them; Crawford discovers that Willy has accepted a job with a major corporate law firm which indicates that his head won't be in the game: Willy sees the case as a slum dunk because he has a written confession, the murder weapon and motive. Crawford and Beachum begin a battle of wits with each trying to out think the other to achieve their goals.END OF SPOILERS**The film looks very nice in its DVD transfer. We get minimal extras here including deleted scenes and alternate endings that differ only slightly from the final version that we see. Whenever a film has multiple endings like this it usually means trouble for the film; a director and the writers usually know where they want to go with the story and have a solid beginning and end. It's the journey between the two that can often be the difficult part here. With a beautiful set up, "Fracture" falters in between. The film really demanded a stronger ending as well although the final version does work quite well because of the weak 2nd and 3rd acts, it doesn't deliver the way it should."Fracture" is entertaining and worthwhile renting particularly if you are a fan of either of the lead actors and both leads give terrific performances it's just a pity that they aren't in a better film.
summary: "Even a clock is right twice a day"..."Fracture" is a broken thriller with some strong performances
